Any world I’ve been to in a game, I’ve
always wanted to go to the edge of it.
To explore every nook and cranny…
To discover everything it had to offer.

That feeling has never gone away, and honestly,
I don’t think it ever will.

With the tools of today though, we can explore
farther and wider than we ever could in the
past…

Which is super helpful when the places you’re
looking to comb through go from instanced,
smaller maps to places the size of galaxies…

Now you may have noticed most notably on my
other channel that I’ve dove headfirst into

the worlds of Super Mario Galaxy 1 and 2 very,
very often.

And honestly, I’m not even half way through
everything there is to explore despite tackling
these games for over a year now.

There’s tons of mysteries I still need to
seek out, and obviously we have a really weird
one which we’ll be talking about today.

So if you watched my video on the mysterious
Dry Bones, you already know that I’ve been

studying this game for a special type of video
that will be released later this year.

YouTuber Collin Hughes is helping me make
that a reality, but during this examination

process there’s been a lot of odd things
to surface.

So, to start off, we need to head on over
to Slipsand Galaxy in World 5.

Slipsand is kind of a bizarre stage because
throughout majority of it we’re winding

around sandy tubes similar in shape to what
one would expect from Gusty Garden Galaxy
in the first game.

So right off the bat, when researching worlds
I always immediately try to see what places
have always been off limits.

Obviously a huge one for Slipsand is the enormous
pyramid that we never really get to actually
check out.

About the only thing we do is fly near it
only to be whisked away on a sand slide as
soon as we land.
So obviously, flying there was a priority.

What’s interesting is despite this giant
pyramid looking like it’d be the perfect

place to run and climb, we actually can’t
interact with it because it lacks collision.

So you just kinda fly through it if you’re
using a flying hack…
Which is kind of a bummer.

The next thing I turned to was the giant pillars
that tower over the level, but the thing is,

they’re actually a part of the skybox so
you can’t actually get to them either.

They don’t move or respond in position despite
how far you travel.

It’s like the edges of the room in Toy Time
Galaxy - you can never touch them.

But this is where things get strange, because
despite how many awesome things this level
offered, it was kind of all a tease…
All except one thing.
Or rather, three things.

While wrapping up work on this particular
level for that video I mentioned earlier,

Collin and I were focusing on the first planet
that you start on in the Galaxy.

It’s the one that looks like a giant sandy
snake, with sand rushing towards you.

On the first star for this galaxy, you normally
make your way to the end and launch off to
the next area.

On the second star, a pipe is in the middle
section which takes you to an underground

area, which then spits you back out on the
first planet.

You then jump on a star and ride over to the
last part of the level.
But let’s rewind that…

Because on the very tip of this planet is
three extra life mushrooms that are pretty
much impossible to achieve.

The thing is, you can never actually see them
because from your perspective it looks like
nothing is over there.

At no point on this entire planet can you
use your camera in first person view to see
whats over the edge of the planet.

Beyond that, the objects would probably be
unloaded anyways due to the distance.

You can make it over to that area on Star
1, but on Star 2, things are changed.

You don’t have to make it to the end of
the planet to progress.

All the sand is rushing towards you in a way
where you can’t long jump quick enough to
make it to the end.

If you go around the entire planet, it’s
the same on all sides.
Rushing sand that you can’t get past.
But there has to be a way, right?

Why would a developer put three extra life
mushrooms at a place impossible to reach?

Anyone playing through his game would never
know they were even there, but there is one
place that does mention their existence.
And it’s in the official strategy guide.

But the thing is, the guide only says there
are three extra lives in the area.

There are no notes on how to actually grab
them.
This is why it is so baffling.
But let’s rule some things out.

First, these one ups are only spawned on Star
2 - Sailing the Sandy Seas.

Choosing any other star means they won’t
be viable since they are unloaded.

Star 2 doesn’t contain any other way to
get back to this planet, as it only has one
launch star leaving it.

So that means in order to obtain these extra
lives, one has to figure out a way to do it
on the planet itself.

Now immediately we of course try to power
through this area by long jumps or spin jumps.

But the thing is, the velocity of the sand
forces Mario or Luigi back so they never actually
make any progress.

So I took a step back and started to think
about the area itself.

The area we come from actually has four dry
bones prior to this sandy river section.

Three are located around the ring, and one
is hidden within a crystal we need to shatter.

This was when I began brainstorming about
how to actually get across, and potentially
what the developer was maybe thinking.

My hypothesis was that if you lured all the
dry bones into the sand, they could walk across

it without getting affected by the pushing
motion.

A lot of times enemies in games don’t behave
the way the players do, so I was thinking
there was a chance this would be similar.

At this point the player would spin off the
heads of each dry bones as they collapses,

basically using them to stall for time from
the raging sand.

Cycling through four dry bones in theory would
give a decent amount of time for the 1st to

recover meaning the player wouldn’t have
to touch the sand as often as before.

The issue is that the dry bones can’t actually
leave this raised section of land though,
despite what you do…
Meaning we’re back at square one.

Without any possibilities available, it seems
like this was the end.

But that’s when Collin decided to take a
few stabs at the challenge.

Since he used to speed run the game and knows
a lot more about it than I do, perhaps he’d
be able to make it across…

And that’s when we discovered just how brutally
annoying this challenge actually is.
It turns out it is possible to cross…

But it’s going to take you five minutes
of spin jumping…
On frame 1 every single time.

The only way your character actually progresses
through the sand is if you make a perfect
spin jump repeatedly overtime.

What that means is you need to initiate a
jump as soon as Mario or Luigi’s foot touches

the ground, get as much horizontal movement
as possible with a spin, and repeat this process
over and over again until your arm aches.

The reason why this is incredibly annoying
to do is if you press the jump button too

early, your press won’t count and the sand
will make you lose like a minute of progress.

On the flip side, if you press the button
too late, you’re already on the ground and
losing progress again.

Only through perfect execution can Mario or
Luigi power through this raging sand to reach
the extra lives on the other side.

A task that was deemed impossible, turned
out to be possible…

But there’s something that still doesn’t
seem right.

Out of any challenge in a Mario game, I’ve
never encountered something this physically
grueling and repetitive.
So that leads me to wonder…
How was someone actually supposed to get these?

Just because we found a way to grab the mushrooms,
doesn’t mean that was the intended method.

Booting up this level in an editor shows that
nothing else exists though.

No hidden objects that are supposed to spawn,
no launch stars that are supposed to bring
us across - absolutely nothing.

So was this just an incredibly hard challenge
put in by a developer, or was the means to

get across accidentally deleted at some point
before launch?

I guess that’s the part of the mystery we’ll
never really know…

But now that I’ve shared all that, have
you ever attempted to grab these?

Or perhaps you have your own story about a
hard to obtain item.

Let me know your thoughts in the comments
below.
